patient_message:
Sample 1 (active treatment):
EHR Context:
Age: 55 years
Gender: Male
Cancer diagnosis: Stage III non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)
PMH: hypertension, hyperlipidemia
Prior cancer treatments: None
Current cancer treatments: radiotherapy with concurrent cisplatin (started 2 weeks ago)
Current medication list: lisinopril, amlodipine, simvastatin, aspirin, pantoprazole
Summary of most recent oncology visit (1 week ago): 55-year-old male with newly diagnosed stage III NSCLC. He is on chemoradiation and tolerating treatment well. No significant side effects were reported. Will continue treatment as planned.

Patient message:
I've been feeling more fatigued than usual for the past week, and I'm having trouble completing my daily tasks. Is this normal? Should I be concerned?


Oh no, I've been feeling more fatigued than usual for the past week, and it's really got me stumped! I'm having trouble completing my daily tasks, and it's quite frustrating, to be honest. Good heavens, is this normal? Should I be concerned that something's going on with my body? Wow, I'm really hoping it's just a minor issue, but a part of me is freaking out, thinking it might be something more serious.

Sample 3 (active treatment):
EHR Context:
Age: 68 years
Gender: Male
Cancer diagnosis: Stage IV colorectal cancer with liver metastases
PMH: coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes
Prior cancer treatments: None
Current cancer treatments: FOLFIRI + bevacizumab (started 2 months ago)
Current medication list: metformin, aspirin, atorvastatin, metoprolol, lisinopril
Summary of most recent oncology visit (6 weeks ago): 68-year-old male with newly diagnosed stage IV colorectal cancer with liver metastases. He is on first-line FOLFIRI + bevacizumab and tolerating treatment well. Will continue treatment as planned.

Patient message:
I've been experiencing severe diarrhea for the past three days. I've tried over-the-counter medications, but they don't seem to help. What should I do?


Oh no, I've been dealing with quite the nasty case of severe diarrhea for the past three days, and it's really got me feeling quite miserable! Good heavens, I've tried all sorts of over-the-counter medications, but woah, they just aren't doing the trick. I'm seriously at my wit's end, wondering what on earth I can do to get some relief. Should I schedule an appointment with my doctor to get to the bottom of this, or is there something else I can try to get my digestive system back on track?

Summary of most recent oncology visit (2 weeks ago): 39-year-old male with newly diagnosed stage IIA Hodgkin lymphoma. He is on ABVD and tolerating treatment well. Will continue treatment as planned.

Patient message:
I've developed a persistent cough and shortness of breath over the past few days. Is this a side effect of my treatment, or should I be concerned about something else?


Oh no, I've been experiencing a really persistent cough and quite frankly, it's been making me feel quite short of breath over the past few days! Good heavens, I'm getting a bit worried that this might be more than just a side effect of my treatment. I'm seriously freaking out, thinking that something else might be going on. Wow, should I schedule an appointment to discuss these symptoms, or is this just my body's way of telling me to take it easy?

Patient message:
I've been experiencing severe nausea and vomiting for the past two days. I've tried over-the-counter medications, but they don't seem to help. What should I do?


  Oh no, I've been feeling absolutely wretched for the past two days, with severe nausea and vomiting that's left me feeling quite drained! Good grief, I've tried over-the-counter medications, but they're just not cutting it – I'm still feeling pretty miserable. Woah, what should I do to get some relief from these awful symptoms? Should I schedule an appointment with my doctor to get to the bottom of this, or is there something else I can try in the meantime?

Good heavens, I'm really starting to freak out here. The pain is quite severe, and I'm seriously worried that I might have done some serious damage. Luckily, I took ativan and it stopped, but I'm still reeling from the shock. What should I do next? Should I schedule an emergency appointment to discuss this with my doctor, or is this just a one-off episode?
